body: @oyamin do you mind adding a test case for this? Also, please squash your commits.
@bolkedebruin Okay then I will add another new pull request :)
I like it, we don't want any logging logic inside of the cli class.

Well, @russellpierce, I must say I am not entirely sure either. I have been using my fork for most of the time. I'll check.

Just had a quick look at the code (current master branch https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/operators/docker_operator.py) but there we just import `Client` from `docker`. So nothing has changed there. I doubt whether this has been fixed then -- this still requires the `docker` module version < 2.0 to be installed...

I think I put the issue to "resolved" to mean: there is a pull request that needs validation. Reopened the issue.
see: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2853
Changes done, rebased and pushed again.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2857?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [8626186...8ffc20f](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2857?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

So, I just realized that the hacks we're using to parse env vars are not complete.
First time I looked at this code and realized we're just using configparser under the hood.
This makes it so `has_option` does not return what you would expect:

```python
In [5]: airflow.conf.has_option('core', 'hostname')
Out[5]: False

In [6]: os.environ['AIRFLOW__CORE__HOSTNAME']
Out[6]: '100.96.4.129'

In [7]: airflow.conf.get('core', 'hostname')
Out[7]: '100.96.4.129'
```

(If the option is not in the config file it can `get` it but does not `have` it. Lol.)
Re-destroyed my history on my branch (with fix being to just not use `has_option` like it was before), so have at it!
Rebased against latest master, fixed conflicts, redestroyed history
LGTM, I would be fine with a `# flake8: noqa` at the top of this file btw. O and as both mysql builds are failing please check that.
LGTM

Great work! Can you create an overarching Jira that splits up the work you intend to do? That helps in keeping the unit of work together. It is fine if the set of 'sub-tasks' changes.

In addition, if the intention is to merge this PR please include a title and descriptive commit message that follow the guidelines.

Obviously to integrate existing tests, including flake8 need to pass ;-).

Please retrigger the build (empty commit, close/open pr) we had a transient error on Travis.

Make sure your commits are squashed.
LGTM
Thanks! Please add jira so I can merge it
I also applied the flask8 style guide.

# [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2860?src=pr&el=h1) Report

As for writing unit tests, you can test out the webserver configuration by (1) configure `web_server_url_prefix` (2) call the web/api endpoints with the custom url prefix (3) check 200 is returned.

I haven't tested this myself, but `__stderr__` seems like explicitly the wrong thing to use given the goal of this ticket:

> sys.\_\_stdin__
> sys.\_\_stdout__
> sys.\_\_stderr__
> 
> These objects contain the original values of stdin, stderr and stdout at the start of the program. They are used during finalization, and could be useful to print to the actual standard stream no matter if the sys.std* object has been redirected.
>
> It can also be used to restore the actual files to known working file objects in case they have been overwritten with a broken object. However, the preferred way to do this is to explicitly save the previous stream before replacing it, and restore the saved object.

(Taken from https://docs.python.org/2/library/sys.html#sys.__stdin__)
@jgao54 What was the error reported by the scheduler? Or no error, but making the change you suggested make it start actually scheduling tasks?
